text: The USA is one of a handful of CONTINENTAL COUNTRIES.   Free trade has made America weak and dependent.   Free Trade has destroyed American manufacturing and cast into perpetual jobless-ness or 'you want fries with that' minimum wage , millions of everyday Americans.  Illegal immigration and under the table wages has destroyed the opportunity for the 'working poor' to obtain long term gainful employment.  The illegal Mexican or Central American immigrant working under minimum wage, without workers compensation gets the jobs the working poor citizen might get.   This illegal employment has a triple effect (1) it removes taxes from the American system (2) it makes American citizens more dependent upon government aid and (3) the illegal immigrants who seek medical care or injure an American can skip out on that responsibility.  The USA is one of the few CONTINENTAL SIZE Countries that is independent on outside food supplies, has sufficient water,  independent energy resources and has EVERY strategic or industrial metal within its borders (save three - one of which is titanium).  The only countries that are similarly resource independent are Russia and Canada.   The three areas where International trade outpaces the USA is (1) cost of labor (2) lack of environmental protection laws and (3) the legal cost of complying with America's employment laws.   To compete on ground (1), the cost of labor ACTUALLY HURTS the average American as it is a race to the bottom on salary and benefits where in the end the American citizen must live like a citizen in Haiti to beat out the low wage and that is a STUPID RACE that we can not win and should not want to win.    The only way to MAINTAIN THE STANDARD OF LIVING IN THE USA...which has dropped for at least 2 decades in relation to the Worlds other countries is to develop a fully functional N. American production and demand economy where we are able to keep the standard of living high and attain full gainful employment at a living wage + benefits.   FINALLY...AMERICA SHOULD NOT NOR SHOULD IT SEEK TO COMPETE WITH THE POOREST COUNTRIES IN THE WORLD REGARDING COST OF LABOR AND THE ONLY WAY TO NOT DO SO IS.....MAKE IT IN AMERICA AND SELL IT IN AMERICA.

text:
The tariffs  exist to bankroll the Rich Fucker Tax Cut
If blocking bootleg and IP infringing goods was the goal, then he would have Embargoed certain chinese products, not tariff them.
To get it through the thick heads of the Right Wingers, I'll use an example from the Firearms market that is found on Amazon: The Atlas Bipod. An American product with a high premium well over $100.
Look below the real thing, and you will find a dozen Chinese knockoffs being offered that are explicit clones of an American design. They sell for $30-60. Are they going to be more expensive than the real thing with a 40% tariff? No.
Did he Embargo them? No, he didn't do that either. He's still letting them be imported and sold here. What he did was make it a bit more expensive for a knockoff, did B&T industries no real favors, and the extra money from the tariff goes to the treasury to help cover the massive revenue loss and infrastructure damage his Rich Fucker Tax Cut is going to cause this country for decades to come. And, of course, a major revenue shortage gives Republicans another shot at ending Social Security and keeping every penny you ever paid into it for themselves and their donors pork projects. text:
@MegaEdouble1 ,
" How much this affects the everyday working man,"  lets see how this plays out.  Here we have an everyday working man. His expertise is assembling washing machines. Currently , washing machines are a little bit cheaper because they are made in China. But , everyday working man can not afford to buy the cheaper washing machine ! Why is that ? Because the job of assembling washing machines is in China. And our everyday working man is NOT working.  There are no jobs for him.
  Who else might be affected by this ? Well , washing machines are made of steel.  The steel for them is being made in South Korea. Not the United States. Which means many former U.S. steel workers are just that, " former " steelworkers. Former well known steel cities such as Youngstown, Ohio now look like  ghost towns. Lots of boarded up stores in Youngstown. Why ? Because steel is "cheaper" from South Korea. If the steelworkers are not working it also means they are not buying cars. At least not the more expensive American cars. If the steelworkers are not working it means that the iron miners of Minn. are also not working.  Nor are the iron ore ships on the Great lakes.
  Washing machines are not the only businesses like this. There are many and the effects spread out like the ripples on a pond from EACH one of those former businesses. 
  I've seen comments about wage stagnation. If a company is not selling enough of it's products it cannot afford wage increases. The Democrats like to blame President Trump for that. It's not his fault. It's been going on for a long time. Bubba sold us out to the Walton's  and China a long time ago .  Remember CAFTA ? That was created especially for the Democrat Walton's.
It turned the Walton's from ordinary billionaires into multi-billionaires !

text: Correct me if I'm wrong, but not ALL of the tariffs will be passed onto American consumers. Chinese sellers can't simply increase their prices by 25% as that would make them less competitive. American consumers/companies would simply buy their products/supplies from other countries or locally. Of course, the costs would likely be higher since China sells cheaper than everyone else due to cheap labor, economies of scale, etc, but it will NOT be 25% higher. Other countries also have scale and cheap labor and it would be no surprise that they are selling at anywhere between 2-10% more expensive than China. In the end, Chinese firms would also have to cut back on profits OR business costs in order to stay in business. We already see many small/medium Chinese factories flocking to Vietnam where overheads are cheaper, in an attempt to lower business costs while preserving as much profit margin as possible. So how much of the tariffs WILL be passed to American consumers? That would depend on the prices that the competitors of China (including local American firms) are selling at. If they sell at 10% more, then American consumers pay 10% more. And that assumes China does not try to compete by undercutting, which if they do then Americans will be even happier. More importantly, we are only talking about the short term. In the longer term, other countries as well as local American factories will increase their production volumes to accommodate to higher American demand and as a result will lower their prices, pushing the extra costs that Americans bear even lower. Again, correct me if I'm wrong, but American consumers will not bear even HALF the costs of the tariffs. Instead, it is China that will be severely impacted and will come out as the bigger loser because for every 10 goods America buys from China, China only buys 2 goods from America (or some similar ratio to that). Therefore, China will be hit 5 times as worse. In order to win, China would have to find other countries to sell to, and this is where America and China will have a fierce competition on bilateral trade agreements (which Trump is very fond of) to try and bring as many countries over to their side as possible. As it stands right now, China has a pretty bad reputation for getting developing countries into debt-traps, plus their style of governance is at odds with those of Western democracies. In the PR war for the worlds nations, it does seem that America would have the upper hand. Long story short, things will be okay in the long term, and even in the short term it ain't that bad. Not to mention, while all this is happening, large amounts of tariff revenues will be pouring in to help with the short term losses. Love to see what the rest of you all think. To clarify, this isn't a scholarly article so obviously I have simplified some things and left out disclaimers, exceptions, etc,  and am just making the main point to keep it short (as if it isn't long enough already).

text:
@Beyonder Sorry, you forget one major concept that the MBA's scream like an autistic child..   PROFIT!!  They may stop using China, but switch to another lower cost center; this is happening inside the States now were Customer Service Call Centers move from city to city, looking for depressed local economies with infrastructure and tax breaks to move into, until the next cheaper area is found.  The only way jobs come back is:
1) Produce something cheaper than anyone else  (Cheap labor, Cheap materials; Can you say FoxConn?)
2) Produce something that no-one else technically can (Intel, but they produce the chips outside the country
3) Produce something that has artistic value or a desired quality that no one else has.  (The Luxury Items... )


The issue is not just faced by United States, it happens to any economy that allows trade with other economies of lower cost. 
Do you want to close all the borders and ports and force things to be built here?   Then all you have to look at is the inflation of Japan, this move would make the US GDP as more worthless than an African nation.  No one wants inflation...  But it happens.


Personally,  here's what I would do to address the mass exodus of manufacturing and wealth protection rackets.
1) Modify the Intellectual Protection (IP) laws that they can only be protected in the United States courts where the company's profits and taxes are collected and invested in the United States.   (IE, none of that off shore 'Headquarters' to route profits.   Sorry Google, and everyone else)
2) Modify the IP laws to offer protection for a shorter period, we've become stagnant, we need to foster continuous innovation. 
3) Stop babying/Protecting the old ideas, Do you know how many stupid things are done to satisfy the protection of old guard models, look up what Taxi Unions have done to cripple progress to keep their profit running, heck, Coal and Oil fighting anything electric and cheaper recurring costs.   We'll cut off a limb because a freaking MBA retard is crying about their dying profit model.   Why do you think that computer printers are so cheap?


Life is a moving target, we're looking for the ultimate comfort and ride it, but with out taking some control we may not like were this ride is going to end.


Ok, I'll get off my soap-box now.   :)

text:
China exports its cars into the US for a 2.5% tariff, but the US exports its cars into China for a 25% tariff. Why? Because previous administrations have been weak in negotiations. Trump is merely levelling the playing field for America and its producers. The US owes China $1.13 trillion. So what? Collectively, the world owes the US $16 trillion. If you want to worry then consider the US' $100 trillion in unfunded liabilities. 



Trump is doing everything he can to create wealth by lowering regulations and taxes for businesses, making the US more energy and product independent, equalizing trade agreements, calling in debts from NATO members and fighting legislation that obstructs legitimate industries and business. And the result is a demonstrably improving economy.

text:
Tariffs achieve similar goal as flat tax.  They help out the rich by taxing the average and poor consumer.  The greater proportion of what you make that you can't afford to invest, the more of what you earn is taxed.  China makes products that average consumers buy.  Shopping, you get the impression that everything is coming from China and the US does not make anything.  That is not the case.  The US is the number 2 exporter in the world.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports  Much more exports per capita.  Trump is playing with fire.  We don't want him to cause other big importers of our goods to slap on big tariffs.  That is what happened during the great depression.  We slapped a big tariff on imports and all those companies retaliated with even bigger tariffs of their own.  Farmers went bully up by the million.  It took decades to get those other countries to undo those tariffs.  And the depression drug on and on.  It took WW2 to really undo it.  Asking for help against the Nazis while having high tariffs on our goods would not have gone over so well.  What could undo it if they did it this time?  It would take a miracle.  There are no big wars anymore.  No one will be in desperate need for us.


And if China makes countries choose a side.  All those other countries will choose China, because China makes the basics, we make equipment for factories that people could buy from Germany or South Korea.


We can't negotiate from strength, our position is shaky.  Scrooge McTrump is playing with fire.  He does not care that you can't buy toys for Christmas, toothpaste, anything at your dollar store, clothing, shoes, a smartphone, or a fan in the summer.

Xi Jinping, the President of China is NOT president for life. His term of office was extended because of his success and is very popular in China, the people support him and his direction he is taking China.

author: bgarr99

text:
@bgarr99 Those are protection tariffs used for specific industries.
Protective tariffs are tariffs that protect a certain domestic industry. Their purpose is to make imported goods cost more than equivalent goods produced domestically.  This encourages sales of domestically produced goods to increase and therefore supports local manufacturers.

How many LED or OLED Flat Screen TVs are made in America? 
Zero
How many digital cameras are made in America?
Zero
How many lithium Ion batteries are made in America?
Zero
How many electronic components such as diodes, capacitors, resistors etc made in America
Zero - except certain Integrated circuits and CPUs 
See where this is going? 
If someone wants to manufacture an audio amplifier say for a Sound bar 2.1 they would have to import almost all of the individual components to make it...or just buy an already made high performance Class D 50 watt x 2 channel & 100 watt sub woofer amplifier with Blue Tooth, and memory card slot for $18 (that you can buy right now online) and sell it at Walmart for $179.
So what idiot would start up a business in America to make these 2.1 amp boards? 
Starting to see the light? üòâ

text:
--Trump‚Äôs Trade War With China Makes Russia Great Again
https://www.cfr.org/blog/trumps-trade-war-china-makes-russia-great-again

--‚ÄúTariffs will make our country much richer than it is today,‚Äù President Trump tweeted in August. So far, there‚Äôs not much evidence of that. As the left-hand graphic above shows, U.S. exports to China have plummeted since June‚Äîwhile U.S. imports from China have continued to rise. Meanwhile, U.S. importers (many of whom are exporters) have seen their U.S. tariff bill more than double since May, topping $5 billion in October.  

--Trump‚Äôs tariff war has some clear winners, however‚Äîhigh among them, Russia. As shown in the left-hand graphic, Chinese imports from non-U.S. firms have continued to grow at a robust 18 percent year-over-year rate while those from U.S. firms have fallen. Among the hardest-hit U.S. sectors have been soybeans, autos, and oil. Whereas China had accounted for about 22 percent of U.S. oil exports in the two years to July 2018, it fell to zero thereafter. This has proven a boon to alternative suppliers like Russia, as shown in the right-hand figure. And so, in the ultimate irony, Americans are paying tariffs that boost the profits of Russian firms subject to U.S. sanctions.
author: W W

text:
Trump Lies Again About ‚ÄòChina Paying Tariffs‚Äô To The U.S. Treasury
The president‚Äôs threat to raise tariffs on Chinese goods would hit American consumers, not China.
https://www.huffpost.com/entry/trump-lies-china-paying-tariffs-to-usa_n_5ccf8704e4b0e4d757347bda

Economists have estimated that the trade war is costing the U.S. more than $3 billion a month.
A University of Chicago study found that consumers paid an extra $1.5 billion for washing machines last year because of a Trump tariff imposed at the behest of Whirpool Corp. that only added $82 million to U.S. coffers. That was because manufacturers got away with charging more for dryers along with washing machines, even though no tariffs were added to the cost of dryers.

text:
--Trump's Tariffs are Effecting our Recycling and its beginning to cost Americans a lot of money and increasing our pollution.  China is no longer buying our recyclables.  

--Is this the end of recycling? 
https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/markets/is-this-the-end-of-recycling/ar-BBUpk8p?li=BBnb7Kz&ocid=mailsignout

--These municipalities have two choices: pay much higher rates to get rid of recycling, or throw it all away.

--Most are choosing the latter. ‚ÄúWe are doing our best to be environmentally responsible, but we can‚Äôt afford it,‚Äù said Judie Milner, the city manager of Franklin, New Hampshire. Since 2010, Franklin has offered curbside recycling and encouraged residents to put paper, metal, and plastic in their green bins. When the program launched, Franklin could break even on recycling by selling it for $6 a ton. Now, Milner told me, the transfer station is charging the town $125 a ton to recycle, or $68 a ton to incinerate. One-fifth of Franklin‚Äôs residents live below the poverty line, and the city government didn‚Äôt want to ask them to pay more to recycle, so all those carefully sorted bottles and cans are being burned. Milner hates knowing that Franklin is releasing toxins into the environment, but there‚Äôs not much she can do. ‚ÄúPlastic is just not one of the things we have a market for,‚Äù she said.

text:
@Hi, it's me No they won't. Complex electronic labor is expensive in China now. It's not made there because of cheap labor. Its made in China because of the supply chain. Because just about every single material, part, conponent, many of the silicon fabs - these things they're all made there too, "right around the corner". Making these products in the US still means cross-continental import of 90-98% of the materials and components from China, South-Korea and Taiwan. All you'd really do in the US, would be assembly. And that extremely more costly supply chain, would ultimately make the finished product cost a helluva lot more than 25% extra. Meaning you're nowhere near competitve, and you go bust.

For your vision to work, the US would have to have an extremely diverse, huge, well-estsblished industry that make all those required components and materials domestically. We don't have that. Building that essential supporting industry would take decades, not months. And still we would need to sell to the rest of the world for that kind of industry and scale to make sense and be viable. Meaning competing with Asia on their de facto global leader turf, where they have half a century head start.

We're better off playing off our own strengths, cultivating and improving those, solidify that in the global market - than clinging to a fantasy about companies that serve a global customer base, would be moving manufacturing away from their sweetspot and to the US, to make their products, t utopian level best case scenario, 5% cheaper for 4-5% of their customer base. While making it more expensive for 95-96% of their customer base, and ultimately lose both competitiveness, money and jobs.

Automation is here to stay too, and US industry is rapidly adopting. Manufacturing and manuf. jobs aren't coming (back) to the US. Ever. Many new jobs will come of the inevitable push towards renewable energy, cleaner industry and trsnsportstion etc, but automation will be the foundation there. Net sum, manufacturing jobs will continue to plummit. People need to learn new trades - and it's never to late to teach an old dog new tricks. What we will be in desperate demand of, is health ans care workers as living age increase, electricians, plumbers, hydralics workers, builders, electrical and mechsnical engineers... and people to assemble, maintain and repair automation equipment. That last one - learn to do that, and you'll never want for work the rest of your life. And it pays well.

text:
@Danny v 
Budget (from French bougette, purse) generally refers to a list of all planned expenses and revenues. It is a plan for saving and spending. [1]A budget is an important concept in microeconomics, which uses a budget line to illustrate the trade-offs between two or more goods. In other terms, a budget is an organizational plan stated in monetary terms. 

In summary, the purpose of budgeting is to: 

Provide a forecast of revenues and expenditures i.e. construct a model of how our business might perform financially speaking if certain strategies, events and plans are carried out. 
Enable the actual financial operation of the business to be measured against the forecast. 
So  in other words, when you take money away from projects that is already allocated for other projects, then something else has to go wanting. Your statement that those monies would be going to projects to build in other nations is at best an assumption. The prior statement about assumption is further supported by your statement about where you think I am from nationally. By that I mean you assume to know what country I'm from. Sad really.

text:
Tariffs are a tax on importers who pass the tax onto consumers.   The net result is less buying power for American consumers and inflation.  And that, fellow citizens, is what will make America Great Once Again!


Trump brags how much the IRS  is taking in on the tariffs from American importers:  "Tariffs will bring in FAR MORE wealth to our Country than even a phenomenal deal of the traditional kind."
Does he understand this money is coming out of the pockets of US consumers...which will not bring wealth but transfer it from their pockets to the government?   Is this one of his schemes to fund the tax breaks for the rich?   


He added: "Our Farmers will do better, faster, and starving nations can now be helped."  Huh?  In fact, American farmers are suffering because  China is meeting US tariffs with tariffs on US goods, including agricultural, which is driving farmers into bankruptcy.


Tariffs Drive Farm Income Down and Equipment Prices Up - The Atlantic
https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2019/03/tariffs-drive-farm.../583684/
Mar 19, 2019 - The higher equipment" costs brought by tariffs are just one part of a global economy that's not particularly friendly to American agriculture these ...
U.S. vs. China trade war: Iowa farmers take another hit as tariffs increase
https://www.desmoinesregister.com/.../agriculture/.../us...farmers...tariffs.../1143730001/


Politico reports: "Trade disputes ‚Äî namely the escalating feud with China ‚Äî have weighed on commodity prices and the president has threatened to ratchet up tariffs rather than ease tensions come Jan. 1. To boot, ordinary business costs like fertilizer and fuel appear to be on the rise, further squeezing bottom lines........The Agriculture Department‚Äôs Economic Research Service has estimated that 2018 net farm income will be $9.8 billion, or 13 percent, lower than the year before. Adjusting for inflation, farm income is barely above the lowest level since 2002. If current trends continue, some agriculture economists predict that farm income will fall again in 2019.

Bill Gordon, a farmer in southwest Minnesota, said his 2,000-acre, family-run operation was on track to break even in 2018 before crop prices went south amid worries of the effect of the trade war. Now, Gordon said, he‚Äôs looking at losses as high as $100,000,


Farm income down 10 billion in 2018....fact.
The rhetoric: ""Our Farmers will do better, faster, and starving nations can now be helped." 


It's all about helping the starving nations, especially in Yemen where the UN reports: "Yemen is on the brink of a historic famine that could put as many as 13 million people at risk of death by starvation, the United Nations warns."




Trump just vetoed the bipartisan resolution to end US  involvement in the genocidal war which is causing half of Yemen's population to be at risk of death from starvation.  He  has also frozen billions in Venezuelan currency , which it was to use to buy food for its people.   His policies are causing starvation, and let us not forget he has proposed cuts in SNAP benefits which currently give the needy about $4.20 a day for their three square meals, $1.40 a meal.  
"According to USDA, more than 41 million Americans face hunger, including nearly 13 million children. Some of the groups experiencing the highest rates of food insecurity include households with children led by single women and people living below the poverty level."

text:
China have played the 
long game, they knew that as an insular, communist, agriculturally 
centrist economy they could never build themselves into a super power 
that could take on the west. So over the last 20 years they have played 
the long game, they opened up their economy to the west and over time 
made themselves the engine room of western economies.
They artificially inflated their growth by building empty 
cities and houses creating a mining boom in Australia. They offered up 
their cheap factory workers to western manufacturing companies luring 
them to China and sending our 
western cities and towns who built themselves around these manufacturing
 industries broke and leaving the citizens dependent on welfare or low 
paid service industry jobs. They cornered the market in the cheap 
manufacturing of everything so that we cannot even make ourselves a pair
 of shoes, EVERYTHING is made in China, in fact 70% of the goods for 
sale in Walmart are MADE IN CHINA.
Now that they have successfully achieved their objective 
it is time for stage two of their strategy, slow their economy and bring
 the west to their knees. Because we are so reliant on the Chinese now 
to buy our mining resources and for their cheap products ie: They make 
our clothes, shoes, homeware, toys, electronics and gadgets when they 
start to slow we are going to be brought to our knees economically too. 
If Walmart don't have cheap products to sell American consumers it's 
going to affect their profit margin, if their profit margins are 
negatively affected they're going to close stores and lay off workers. 
It's not just a matter of returning to the days where we manufactured 
these products ourselves (like the majority of Trump cultists believe) 
because we don't have a manufacturing industry to make anything anymore 
and it would take years to build them back up to the level to replace 
everything we have outsourced to China.
Let's also not forget the MASSIVE amount of debt that the US are in to 
China or how badly they are already hurting the American agricultural 
industry by refusing to buy soybeans.
Then with our markets crashing and our economy hemorrhaging they will 
strike, hard and fast, the blindside will be brutal.

text:
I REALLY wish someone would sit Trumpster down with a picture book that explains how tariffs actually work. Trumpster has made it clear in his stupid tweets that he thinks tariffs are paid by China directly to the US Treasury. The more we slap on the tariffs, the more China is paying the US. If we have more tariffs than China, we're making more than China. Which is why he keeps doing it and says it's good for America.

And he is completely wrong. 

Tariffs have their place in trade to help even out some differences when it comes to imports hurting domestic production. But it can't successfully be used as a long-term, mass weapon. And since the importers pay the actual tariffs, those added taxes are usually passed on to the consumer in increased retail prices as part of the package. Add on to that the taxes being used to boost farmers pockets for the lost income due to the tariffs. WE are the ones paying for this.

The idiot in the White House who has no grasp of economics is hurting the average citizen.

https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-who-pays-for-tariffs-trade-war-costs-2019-1

https://www.factcheck.org/2019/05/trump-exaggerates-tariff-revenue/

text:
@Timmy the Poker Warrior What is a Tariff?

A tariff is a tax imposed by one country on the goods and services imported from another country.

How a Tariff Works

Tariffs are used to restrict imports by¬†increasing¬†the price of¬†goods and services purchased from another country, making them less attractive¬†to domestic consumers. There are two types of tariffs: A specific tariff is levied as a fixed fee based on the type of item, such as a $1,000 tariff on a car. An¬†ad-valorem¬†tariff is levied based on the item's value, such as 10% of the value of the vehicle.

text:
Even a rookie economist can explain why trade tariffs are bad on those that impose them on others. US citizens will pay more for Chinese products thus eventually buy less of them. China will then offer better deals to it's other trading partners so they can off load they're overproduction. US citizens lose, the rest of the world wins. Tariffs are a form of protectionism, protectionism stymies productivity improvements and cost reduction. Protectionism limits consumer choice, Protectionism restricts free markets and competition. The consumer is the loser. The agriculture sector is the loser. The manufacturing sector is the loser.
What else would you expect from a bankrupt and tax evader?

author: Adam Eaton

text:
President Donald Trump's TARIFFS  are working....,
U.S. manufacturing employment has now shown year-on-year growth of more than 250,000 employees for 12 consecutive months. That's the largest and most sustained manufacturing job growth since 1998...
Critics of President Trump's tariffs say price increases on tariffed goods hurt "downstream" companies in metal-using industries that have to buy raw steel and aluminum. However, these same industries are now thriving and hiring workers more rapidly than the metal industries themselves.

How can that be?

The answer is that price increases are getting passed down the supply chain. And at the end of the chain, consumers are buying the goods because their incomes are rising.

This illustrates a fundamental fact of the U.S. economy: Many markets are made up of just a few sellers, and they all tend to raise prices together. In a growing economy, consumers who are feeling confident about the future simply pay the price increases...

By cutting taxes and embarking on deregulation last year, the Trump administration gave a boost to the economy. This is helping consumer incomes rise. At the same time, the tariffs are stimulating domestic U.S. manufacturing. So all boats are rising..

Tariffs work to deliver a boost to the U.S. economy in two ways. First, they make foreign goods more expensive, which shifts demand to American-made products. And second, they give industry a sense of confidence in the future...MAGA

1. No significant differences between old and new NAFTA deal. Main difference is now it has a stupid name trump tried to give it that no one uses. See Reference 1.

2. New NAFTA still unratifed, will probably die on the table, see Reference 2.

Reference 1:
Jean Chretien says Donald Trump is "unspeakable" and his rise to the U.S. presidency heralds the decline of the American empire
https://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/chretien-says-rise-of-unspeakable-trump-marks-end-of-the-american-empire-1.4127123
"... October 9, 2018...
Chretien unleashes that unflattering opinion of Trump in a new book of anecdotes from his 10 years as Canada's prime minister .
...
Chretien also weighed in on the renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which Trump has renamed the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement. The 14 months of tortuous negotiations and repeated threats by Trump to rip up NAFTA and impose ruinous auto tariffs on Canada turned out to be "a lot of talk for nothing," he said .
"He changed the name and not much else," Chretien said, adding that the NAFTA partners made "a little bit of an adjustment but basically we still have a free trade agreement with them that will work about the same way that it was working before."
..."

Reference 2:
Trump 'messed up the clock' on USMCA, current form 'dead': former U.S. ambassador
https://beta.ctvnews.ca/national/politics/2019/5/3/1_4407446.html
‚Äú... May 3, 2019 ...
OTTAWA ‚Äì U.S. President Donald Trump has "messed up the clock" on getting the renegotiated NAFTA deal ratified, and it may now die in its current form, says former U.S. Ambassador to Canada Bruce Heyman.
In an interview on CTV's Question Period, Heyman said that the deal in its current form is dead.
After nearly 14 months of negotiations, the trilateral trade pact was reached last fall, and signed a short while later. It is called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, or USMCA in America, and the Canada-United States-Mexico-Agreement, or CUSMA, here.
The deal has been heralded as a win by all three countries although concessions were made, including on access to Canada's supply-managed sectors. Since the signing, all attention has been focused on ratification given that the existing NAFTA will remain in place until its revamped version is fully ratified.
As things stand, time is diminishing on that possibility given the amount of movement that would have to happen across North America over the next six weeks. That‚Äôs when Parliament rises for the last time before the October election will be called.
Among the obstacles yet to overcome: In the U.S. Democrats have said that the deal without changes won‚Äôt have their vote, nor will they allow a vote in Congress until Mexico changes its labour laws. In addition to these sticking points, Canada will not sign the deal so long as the U.S.-imposed steel and aluminum tariffs are in place.
"Let me be really clear that the USTR [United States Trade Representative] and Donald Trump mishandled this from day one. Had they just quickly passed a deal in 2017, signed an agreement between the three countries‚Ä¶ in early 2018, he had the Congress, he had the Senate, he had the Mexican government in place, and there were no elections coming up here," Heyman said.
"He could have passed it, scored a victory, and it's done. They messed up the clock. Second, they did not collaborate or communicate with unions, nor did they work with the Democrats. So now they find themselves in a position where the Democrats, and the unions in the United States have a different perspective," he said.
Heyman said that Republicans have been pushing Trump to drop the tariffs, which were imposed by the U.S. last spring in the midst of NAFTA talks, citing national security concerns as their justification.
Canada responded with its own dollar-for-dollar countermeasures on American steel, aluminum, and other goods. Canadian officials have already said these retaliatory measures would be lifted the minute the Americans dropped their tariffs, though the governing Liberals have been criticized by the opposition for not resolving the damaging trade action before inking the deal.
"I think he's in a really bad place on this deal," Heyman said of Trump.
Heyman, who was joined by his wife Vicki on Sunday‚Äôs episode of CTV‚Äôs Question Period, also spoke at length about the pair‚Äôs newly-published book "The Art of Diplomacy." The book details their time in Ottawa, which included being ‚Äúiced out‚Äù as then- U.S. president Barack Obama's representative in Canada, by the then-Stephen Harper government over the Keystone XL pipeline battle, and more.
...‚Äù

text:
In August 1989, just two months after Trump launched his Trump Shuttle Airline, one of his Boeing 727s made a crash landing at Boston‚Äôs Logan International Airport.¬† The shuttle was to fly white-collar passengers between New York, Washington and Boston. The passenger jet had malfunctioning nose gear that failed to deploy. The nose and underbelly of the plane scraped and dragged along the runaway upon landing, with sparks flying. The pilots had to perform an emergency dumping of fuel to avoid a greater catastrophe. It's all on video.
Trump purchased the airline for 365 million, and in 3 years, it never turned a profit.üòÑ

And when Trump was asked by reporters about the crash landing in Boston, he said, and I quote: ‚ÄúIt was the most beautiful landing you‚Äôve ever seen." üò≤üò®

Back in 1986 and likely for many years before, Trump colluded in tax evasion with¬†Bulgari Jewelry Store¬†in NY, a high-end posh location with tony clientele right out of¬†Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous. Here's how the scam worked:

Trump would go into the store with his wife, his girlfriend, his...whatever (to use his vernacular). He would then buy her an expensive necklace or wristwatch. Normally, such a transaction would face the NY and state sales tax, which would be pretty high on luxury jewelry.

In an illegal attempt to evade the tax, Trump "asked" the store to instead ship the jewelry to an out of state location, where no NY sales tax could be collected. In fact, the store would merely send an empty jewelry box to the location, while Trump and his lady friends walked out the door with the jewelry that very day.

The state and city tax collectors eventually caught onto this scheme, and¬†Trump promptly testified¬†against his erstwhile tax evasion colluding partners at the jewelry store in order to save his own skin.üò≤ Anyone who gets close to a disease like Trump will end up getting pushed off a curb by him, and into an oncoming bus.

The empty box scam is just one example of Trump's history of illegal tax evasion. Another story can be told about his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida by local reporter¬†Frank Cerabino.
Trump bought the property from the estate of breakfast cereal heiress Marjorie¬†Merriweather Post. He got it for a relative bargain at $7.5 million, something he bragged about in¬†The Art of the Deal. Yet he refused for years to pay local property¬†taxes on the actual value of the property, $11.5 million at the time he bought it. He tried to have it both ways--buy the property for a steep discount and also pay property taxes at¬†that same under-valued¬†level.

Try that with your town's property tax assessor sometime and see what he says.üò≤

text:
President Donald Trump's TARIFFS  are working....,
U.S. manufacturing employment has now shown year-on-year growth of more than 250,000 employees for 12 consecutive months. That's the largest and most sustained manufacturing job growth since 1998...
Critics of President Trump's tariffs say price increases on tariffed goods hurt "downstream" companies in metal-using industries that have to buy raw steel and aluminum. However, these same industries are now thriving and hiring workers more rapidly than the metal industries themselves.

How can that be?

The answer is that price increases are getting passed down the supply chain. And at the end of the chain, consumers are buying the goods because their incomes are rising.

This illustrates a fundamental fact of the U.S. economy: Many markets are made up of just a few sellers, and they all tend to raise prices together. In a growing economy, consumers who are feeling confident about the future simply pay the price increases...

By cutting taxes and embarking on deregulation last year, the Trump administration gave a boost to the economy. This is helping consumer incomes rise. At the same time, the tariffs are stimulating domestic U.S. manufacturing. So all boats are rising..

Tariffs work to deliver a boost to the U.S. economy in two ways. First, they make foreign goods more expensive, which shifts demand to American-made products. And second, they give industry a sense of confidence in the future...MAGA

Beamers Beamer    For eight years, President Obama presided over the worst economic recovery in modern times. For six years, he blamed Republicans in Congress for thwarting his spending agenda and hampering growth. In his last two years in office,  Obama claimed that 2% growth was the best we could hope for. 
And in his last year in office, while the economy was again stalling out, Obama claimed that Trump's tax cuts and deregulation would only make things WORSE ....

He lied .... again 

But now that we're in the midst of a Trump booming economy ‚Äî which kicked in AFTER  Trump reversed almost all Obama's economic policies...
The rate of GDP growth was decelerating in Obama's last year. 

In Obama's last year, unemployment rate remained basically unchanged ‚Äî it was 4.9% in Jan 2016, and 4.8% when Trump took office in Jan. 2017. Now it's down to 3.9%...

Consider that a survey of 68 business, financial and academic economists by The Wall Street Journal at the start of this year found that most believed Trump's policies would boost the economy, while the same group had said Obama's policies were a drag on long-term growth. Ninety percent said Trump's tax cuts would accelerate growth.   
It did.

text:
@Brian C 25% tariffs is not enough for businesses here to consider the much higher expenses of domestic production worthwhile. Passing tariff cost onto the consumer is how they WILL respond, here and in China.
Be prepared for higher expenses, less quality to cut costs, massive dislocation to integrated businesses in both countries that costs more jobs, not creates them and turbulence in the stock market that devalues holdings by tens of billions as happened last week. Trump may have went to business school 50 years ago but he doesn't understand how the world economy works. Saying "Trade wars are great and easy to win," has never, ever been true. And tariffs only ever help a few at the expense of many. Whatever tariff money the U.S. or Chinese treasuries pocket our economies lose more. And the consumer feels the pain either way, we're the ones who pay the tariffs in the end. That's how it always works out, it's that simple, and Trump either doesn't understand or care..

text:
@ SnarlaRae ...I don't upload a lot anymore, not really much more I can add to the information I have already provided and what I have warned about. I will post this here because you are familiar with my channel, this is what I posted about China in my group on MeWe where I still provide daily observations and updates. 

China have played the 
long game, they knew that as an insular, communist, agriculturally 
centrist economy they could never build themselves into a super power 
that could take on the west. So over the last 20 years they have played 
the long game, they opened up their economy to the west and over time 
made themselves the engine room of western economies.
They artificially inflated their growth by building empty 
cities and houses creating a mining boom in Australia. They offered up 
their cheap factory workers to western manufacturing companies luring 
them to China and sending our 
western cities and towns who built themselves around these manufacturing
 industries broke and leaving the citizens dependent on welfare or low 
paid service industry jobs. They cornered the market in the cheap 
manufacturing of everything so that we cannot even make ourselves a pair
 of shoes, EVERYTHING is made in China, in fact 70% of the goods for sale in Walmart are MADE IN CHINA.
Now that they have successfully achieved their objective 
it is time for stage two of their strategy, slow their economy and bring
 the west to their knees. Because we are so reliant on the Chinese now 
to buy our mining resources and for their cheap products ie: They make 
our clothes, shoes, homeware, toys, electronics and gadgets when they 
start to slow we are going to be brought to our knees economically too. 
If Walmart don't have cheap products to sell American consumers it's 
going to affect their profit margin, if their profit margins are 
negatively affected they're going to close stores and lay off workers. 
It's not just a matter of returning to the days where we manufactured 
these products ourselves (like the majority of Trump cultists believe) 
because we don't have a manufacturing industry to make anything anymore 
and it would take years to build them back up to the level to replace 
everything we have outsourced to China.
Let's also not forget the MASSIVE amount of debt that the US are in to China or how badly they are already hurting the American agricultural industry by refusing to buy soybeans.
Then with our markets crashing and our economy hemorrhaging they will strike, hard and fast, the blindside will be brutal.
